headline: Unreflective Experience of J.P. Morgan
pros:
- Remote working
- Annual bonus
- Competitive salary
- Many internal teams to join to suit your interests
- Covers work station expenses
cons:
- Mentorship could be improved as at the time the method for mentoring was to either sink or swim. Understandably, this is the industry norm but more guidance could be given especially for someone at the early stages of their career.

- HR could take internal matters more seriously: Complaints and suggestions enter the void at the company, maybe this is due to working at a large company but you would expect more from an industry leading employer.

headline: Toxic culture shock
pros:
Made good friends.
Nice cafeteria options.
cons:
Title worship.
Toxic middle-managers in tech.
Absent leadership who only wants to be put on a pedestal and worshipped.
A lot of busy work. Manual, tedious and draining workload. Lots of people who talk a lot of technical nonsense about architecture but don’t have the skill to back it up. Just the title..
They want a blend of toxic and skill based personality in leadership that keeps the alpha culture going ( could be male female or other person that is driving this alpha culture of a bygone era).
I went in to jpmc as a confident person but came out in about a year with low self-esteem and always second guessing my decisions ( my manager would micromanage, yell, talk down to me in front of others).

headline: Love the company, can't stand current trend for branches.
pros: Great benefits, paid holidays, vacation time.
cons: Giving more access to tellers (associate bankers) and then cuting staff making it impossible to cover teller line while having to sit down at desks to solve complex needs. Bare minimum staffing makes call offs/vacation time a nightmare. Tellers now expected to open personal and business accounts with no incentive. Also call centers are pure chaos, it's russian roulette that you'll get a rep who actually knows what they're doing - and most things require a phone call do to no access at branch level. All other branch positions are either sales or management, and with no work from home opportunities you have to go to the city - currently looking outside of the company for new work opportunities.

headline: Not the brand it once was
pros:
Starting salary - you will need to negotiate well as they will low-ball you, but you can get a decent hike. Ensure its something you can live off for a few years because it will barely be raised.

Name on the resume - externally people still highly regard the name

You will test your mental health and resilience 

You will become accustomed to accepting peoples resignations
cons:
Even if you have decades of experience you will be treated like a child.

Jamie and his millionaire management keep all pay rises and bonuses to themselves. 

Technology is decades old.

Bureaucracy kills everything. 

Marcomms is the most inept department I’ve ever been apart of, it is lead by press for press. They constantly remind the wider team how busy and great they are and take the majority of promotions and pay/bonuses.

Micro-Management and bulling across the team/firm.

Loads of weekly meetings for absolutely no reason.

Promotions for failure, a manager had all their staff resign, they were subsequently promoted.

Constant back to work drive - they are not building a new HQ for you to sit at home, along with repeated attempts to coerce & force individuals to get vaccinated.

DE&I agenda actively discriminates against a large proportion of the firm.

Weekly emails to constantly remind you what to think and do, whilst management do as they please as long as targets are hit. It feels more like an adult play group than a workplace.

I can think of 23+ resignations off the top of my head within the last 2 years which is shocking given the pandemic, I’ve probably even forgot some.

The US office culture is horrific, management sit in offices looking down on the worker ants holed up in depressive cubicles. London office culture is better I believe although the US are doing their best to destroy it, it won’t be long until the best members of staff leave and its already started to happen.

headline: Great Benefits But the Pay is Not Good
pros: Great benefits package.  Military friendly.  I had a co-worker that was out for an entire year due to a medical emergency and they still received compensation and medical benefits.  The benefits are truly top notch.  Very affordable as well and great life insurance to boot.
cons: Note:  This is in regards to the call center and not a branch or technical position.  It is very rigid.  Leadership is chosen solely based on performance which ignores a leaders ability to actually lead.   Performance metrics are antiquated and impossible to understand.   There are a lot of contradictory policies and confusion as to duties within a role.  You need a manager to do anything.  I have close to 10 years in the company and that means next to nothing.   They offer tuition assistance but don't allow for any flexibility in your work schedule to attend course (this is only in my current role and was not the case in past roles).

headline: Not Woman friendly.  Disorganized. Harmful. D
pros: Salary. Benefits. Company Size. Colleagues on other teams.
cons:
Within J.P. Morgan Wealth Management, Technology, Self Directed Investing specifically the work environment is one where women are few and planning resignations at a dramatically high rate for the number of women working here. The CTO and various male colleagues across ranks (definitely Executive Directors and Vice Presidents across the board) are verbally abusive to women, they don't listen to women and they act like when women bring up fact they are crazy or problematic. Facts don't matter here only what men in positions of power say and do.
You have no choice but to push back and when you do you are blamed for all of their pitfalls.
It is unhealthy and I do not recommend to any woman/womxn to work here. There are many great places as JPM is a great company. This is not it. 
Many women have left and are leaving. So as long as this is the culture it will not be a good place to work.
JPM is a great company and should not be defined by this one space. It has many women in positions of power and positions where they help , mold and cultivate others. Also many men outside of this group who are competent, intelligent, helpful and help others by upholding the code of conduct at the company. Overall an amazing place. This group is not and needs new leadership.

headline: Lofty image...possibly dismal reality, depending on your department / management
pros:
- Commitment to diversity, equity and inclusion
- Strong reputation, experience at JPM enhances one's resume
- Smart, driven, COMMITTED colleagues
-Good tuition reimbursement plan
- Very strong internal learning and training platforms
cons:
- Your team may be mercilessly overworked. My team routinely worked evenings, weekends and part of our vacations (I started tracking my hours- they amounted consistently to >60 /wk)
-Persistent high turnover and understaffing. Experienced employees may find that they need to extensively coach new hires, even while dealing with crushing deadlines
- Brisk pace and high volume of strategy and procedural changes being pushed down to rank & file staff, at a time when the team is already struggling just to achieve the core job, due to persistent turnover/understaffing
- 401K Match is credited to your personal 401K account on only ONE DAY EACH YEAR (early February). If you are vested n the 401K but leave JPM on 15 January - you will NOT receive your accrued, pro rata company match. This is a stingy, employee-unfriendly, and frankly, INDEFENSIBLE 401K match policy for an employer of JPM's stature and means.
-Medical and Dental plans are merely average, and there was no High Deductible Health plan option as of the Oct 2021 Open Enrollment
- You may NEVER have any time to avail yourself of the Tuition benefit, or even the robust internal learning and training offered by JPM.

headline: Find something else more meaningful unless you enjoy Call center Jobs
pros: benefits such medical, dental, 401k matching up to 5%, vested after 3 years, cafeteria (depending on your location) is pretty decent
cons: Having to deal with agitated customers, policies that doesn't really benefit the customers at all (still wonder why people bank here), too many back to back calls, micromanaged to the very last detail and no sort of help from management when it comes to people suffering with mental health. If you want to move up, be prepared to be kissing some butts and say yes ma'am yes sir all the time. I'm not into that corporate lingo. And may I add that they base your performance on what they call a scorecard that summarizes your monthly goals either that you met or failed at

headline: Opportunities but also frustrations
pros:
Ton of room for professional growth and a lot of people to learn from.
When the CEO earns millions annually, the sky the limit with how high you can advance in pay.
In recent years, there is strong push to invest in ongoing learning to existing employees.
When working for number one in most industries it competes, large room for impact.
Generous vacation policies!
cons:
Tendency towards big too slow. Exceptions exist, but without someone enthusiastic pushing things forward the default would be to move slow and cautiously.
Poor work-life balance.
Teams throughout the world means impossible task of accommodating to every time-zone. Frequently, up early or late or up late to make meetings.
Culture of too many meetings. Everything becomes a group discussion which takes away from development time.
As can happen anywhere, politics and personal agendas can sway more than the "best" decision at any time.

headline: CRE Term Lending
pros: There currently isn't anything positive going on with Commercial Real Estate Term Lending located in Irvine, Dallas
cons: Sales, Processing, Credit and Closing are all on different pages. Sales folks and managers tend to talk down the Processing (LC), have made many people cry, if an LC didn't MOC the file sales would call that person and pressure them to MOC date it so they would get paid. LC's are overworked and upper management is out of touch with the large turn over. Upper management knows there's a huge issue and HR is aware as well, but nothing ever changes, and management and LC turnover is high and increases every year.

headline: Great career starter, not great beyond that.
pros:
Competitive Incoming Salary
Great philanthropy opportunities
Good benefits
Looks good on a resume
Lots of mobility opportunity to move location or switch careers
Training opportunities for what they bring in house are great but if you want something outside their organizational negotiations will be hit or miss.
cons:
Long term employment isn't great. They don't care about employees long term and it's honestly detrimental to stay there beyond 4-5 years. There's a saying "You have to leave and come back to get a decent pay raise" and it's so true. They'll spend cash to bring you in but aren't really interested in spending cash to retain you. 
JPMC likes to bend rules when it's in their favor, but the environment is cutthroat and heavily political. If you screw up at all, don't expect anyone to back you as you will be held 100% accountable even if it wasn't your fault or you were told to do so.

headline: Mixed
pros: Great prospects, highly competitive pay and generally excellent people in my team/department
cons:
Intense pressure and unmanageable workload at times in my role - weeks at a time of 12+ hours shifts in a new and uniquely challenging role with little support on the trading desk with few/no opportunities for any real break in addition to being expected to regularly entertain clients after hours. 

Uncompromising bureaucratic machine resulting in a generally inflexible and unsympathetic approach when it came to dealing with a personal disciplinary issue that occurred after a particularly intense/stressful period.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
In a big company like this alot will depend on your team and manager; so my experience may not be yours. But at least for me, the work life balance is great. I know some people complain they work too much, but I have never felt the compuction to work more then my normal hours, except the odd half hour here or there. I made it known very early on when my day is done im gone. I think people that are doing long hours have trouble laying that line down. 

I have had a lot of opportunities to learn new technologies and work and exciting new projects. Honestly this the best job i've had to date.

The pay and benefits are good as well.
cons:
Bureaucracy can be a bit of an issue here.

Thier forcing us to come back to the office 3 days a week to spite us all working from home successfully for the last 2 years.

Pay here is good, but it could be better.

Getting promoted to VP and above is alot about the people you know.

headline: Decent Position with Good Pay and Overtime
pros:
* Overtime Availability for Retail Department
* Mental Health was talked about and the on-site counselor was available (something I’ve never had with a job before)
* Coachings we’re given to prevent any later action of a Performance Improvement Plan or Written Warning
* Great Sick, Vacation, Personal, Volunteer Time (can’t beat it elsewhere)
* Meals were offered to on-site workers when the pandemic first began
* If you come to work, do your job well, and know who to avoid (few ones in upper management) you’ll be just fine here. Very simple.
cons:
* Please keep your distance and learn to deal with corrupt managers that abuse their power at the Katy Fwy location. I can’t list names to tell you who to look out for unfortunately but you’ll see it for yourself in the meantime.
* If your end of year ranking is not so great like some of my colleagues you have to choose your new schedules from the leftovers ex. 2:00PM-11:00PM who wants to do that?
* There’s tons of verbal abuse that happens during calls here and there be we were still expected to be level headed.

headline: Good Opportunity with Great Benefits
pros:
- Good benefits such as the starting salary being $65,000 / annually for an in-experienced analyst
- Dental plan is under $20/month for a single person
- Health insurance is under $150/month for a single person
- Every 3 years you can re-qualify for the $1,100 work from home reimbursement to update your equipment
- Great experience and looks good on your resume
- Opportunity to grow within 2+ years of being in your position
- Generous vacation time
- Able to work in the Salesforce tower downtown
cons:
- No parking reimbursement which is expensive around downtown Indianapolis
- You don't qualify for tuition reimbursement or any sort of tuition help until after one year of being employed
- Vacation was limited in that you had 3 weeks worth as well as sick days but it had to be scheduled all at once well in advance (as if people are going to know when they're going to be sick) and that was only due to the manager choosing for it to be that way and not being able to take off on the same day as another teammate
- My manager ended up being a complete control freak, micromanager, and highly concerned with making her look good especially to the Vice President (her manager)
- Training was incredibly difficult as you're screen sharing with other people and the system lags a lot
- HUGH lack of diversity even though this corporation screams diversity and inclusion yet it only seems to be for show
- They will fire you at any time without notice due to petty things like not responding to a skype message fast enough

headline: Great place to start a career
pros: Great place to start a career. Across the cybersecurity org there are some really great leaders, but also some really awful leaders. If you're lucky enough to have a great leader - life will be good, otherwise - not so much. JPMC offers great benefits overall. This includes 401k match, 20 vacation days (6 sick, 3 personal), paid holidays, tuition reimbursement. Cybersecurity has a decent training budget and always brings in the best cyber trainings.
cons: Leaders across the cybersecurity org are authorized to work full remote, but they don't allow middle managers and individual contributors to do so. The 'do as I say not as I do' is a bit ridiculous, especially after working years remote because of the pandemic and showing the job can be done. There's also a lot of office politics. Promotions more often than not seemed to be based on popularity and not on merit. And lastly, JPMC base salary / total comp isn't competitive at the associate and VP level anymore.

headline: Does not value employee health and wellbeing
pros: Reasonable pay, lots of room for growth within the company. Tries to hire within, to allow employees to grow.
cons:
Return to office strategy seems like it was designed to have employees get covid. First they sent us back too soon, then they announced a more aggressive strategy to return to office - breaking social distancing, having days where 100% of staff is at the office. Then a week later announce masks were 100% optional where legally possible. 

They also took accommodation options away and restricted the definition of high risk. This after praising us in 2020 saying that our production did not drop after starting to work from home.

I've never felt less valued as an employee.

headline: Eh
pros: Great benefits, okay salary, good overtime pay and yearly raises. They have written rules and regulations that can be found by any employee. It's an alright job if you do exactly as you're told, arrive early daily and enjoy long hours.
cons: Overworked. No say in anything, they try to make you feel heard but it's just for show. You are micromanaged down to the millisecond; prepare to get to work at least 10 minutes early every day to make sure your ancient computer boots up fast enough for you to clock in on time. If you log in even a minute or two late more than a few times, prepare for a very uncomfortable conversation with your boss. They love to call everyone "family" which is manipulative. If you deny overtime, again, prepare for another uncomfortable conversation with your boss. Work, work, work, work, that's all this company knows. They are big enough that if you quit, retire or even die, they can fill your spot in a second. They do not care about you. Also, they do not care if you are being harassed or bullied by your coworkers, unless someone straight up hits you or inflicts some sort of physical pain unto you, HR doesn't care.

headline: Lack customer service skills
pros: It is easy to make an apointment because they are not busy.
cons: This bank that I worked for for over 20 years has lost its connection with the customer base. Chase is now about the bottom line and charges unreasonable fees to the everyday customer. Their focus has changed to the “elite” customers and Chase has lost touch with the everyday customer that represented 75% of the customer base at the branch In Brunswick,Ohio. I witnessed a loan officer refinance a mortgage with a family for a lower interest rate but the majority of the mortgage payment went to the interest., not the principal. This family made 15 years of payments and their mortgage balance was only reduced $10,000 in that 15 years of payments. Our recent changes in bank personnel are uncaring, impatient and rude and I have since left the company after 20 years of employment.

On the day I was meant to receive a job offer after good news they randomly scrapped the job without warning and basically left me on the wayside after months and months of interviewing, determination, and effort. It's actually wrong and immoral.

headline: Good first job but terrible for career growth
pros:
Really good schemes for graduates and retraining non-computer science graduates, veterans and those returning to work after a career break

Good perks like private healthcare

Salary is good for graduates

If you are lucky you will get a good team that have interesting projects and/or good managers that don't take you for granted

They are building a nice new Glasgow office
cons:
Technology & Career Growth

Outdated technology and mundane programming tasks. Code quality is poor. Too many ‘Yes’ men push untested code into production on a regular basis to get things out quicker to impress management.

Absolutely no time or resources dedicated to training or personal growth. Any training you do get is minimal and you have to fight for it. If you are not diligent at spending time outside of work learning new technologies, you will be left behind. 

There is a lot of internal technology to keep people trapped in their jobs with no transferable skills. Avoid CIB and ‘Athena’ for this reason. 

Half the job is being on support or calls rather than coding. No concept of agile or proper programming practices. Those who have been at JP Morgan for a while are very stuck in their ways and refuse to try anything new. 

It is very hard to try anything new because of all the red tape. 

Compensation

Once you roll off the graduate scheme, your pay rises become minimal. Those who just completed the grad scheme are getting paid substantially more than associates who rolled off the grad scheme two years prior. As soon as you get promoted to associate, get yourself out of there! 

Record breaking profits in pandemic haven’t reached workers who have hardly had pay rise in 2 years (at least in Glasgow), yet CEO gets 9.5% pay rise this year.

Work Culture

Promotions based on box ticking rather than meaningful contributions. People who are the backbone of their team are often overlooked and management take them for granted. 

Many stay at JP Morgan for their whole career and focus too much on getting promoted (not their fault, the culture is rewarding the wrong behaviour) and playing politics rather than becoming better software engineers.

Forced return to the office despite majority of employees prefer working from home. They are expecting 3 days a week in the office for tech staff. I was forced to go back into the office for a day to ‘show face’ last year and there was 5 people on my floor in that day.. 

Toxic work culture and pressure to do longer hours and even weekend work. American colleagues answering emails at 4am and on their days off. Colleagues in India are expecting to work 12+ hours regularly and not appreciated at all. It is a depressing work environment.

‘Asked’ to work weekends with no compensation in terms of pay or time off with little notice. I had to work 12 days in a row a few times and was not given anything in return, and when I tried to ask for 2 days back I was told I could leave an hour early on the Friday.. 

Managers are not given enough training and it shows. I had a manager that told me that I had to stop leaving at 5pm and put in more hours if I wanted to be taken seriously, despite me having one of the highest work outputs on the team. He also made a lot of unprofessional comments about the diversity training that made me very uncomfortable.

headline: VP Product Owner - 10+ yrs experience
pros:
It took years but I finally have a great work life balance. It depends on your role expectations, team dynamic and definitely appetite of your manager in terms what type of flexibility you can get. 
Established roles which limit the unknown - when interviewing if you ask about role expectations and specifics, you should get a clear answer. Not much is undefined.
Great opportunities to continue your education and upskill yourself for the future - endless really. Tuition assistance is wonderful 
Lots of Business Resource Groups to get involved in - supporting Women, Blacks, Hispanics, Asians, those with Disabilities etc. 
Plenty of networking opportunities - internal mobility is looked highly upon and many take advantage.
cons:
Benefits are very expensive which is surprising for such a large company
Depending on the team - cultures vary greatly and you may come across very uncollaborative colleagues
People are overworked so tend to have negative attitudes at times - but they are great people 
Do more with Less has been a constant over my tenure. 
Hard to hire good people due to low compensation - hard to retain for same reason.
CEO has a broad brush negative attitude towards the concept of remote workers and their productivity which is out of touch. Will be difficult to find any remote opportunities.

headline: Great culture and colleagues
pros: great colleagues, good benefits, annual bonus, retirement plan, hmo + 2 dependents - option to cover and pay for dependents above 65 (this is deducted from employee salary but still, where will you find a company that allows your parents 65+ to have insurance)
cons: work life balance always remains a goal.

headline: It's been ok. Not too great not too bad. Just ok.
pros:
Internal mobility. Great! But read the cons to know more. 
No tooo much work pressure, it's pretty decent and manageable/ doable.
cons:
No proper hike for promotions, they use internal employees for a vacant position rather than taking someone from outside and provide them with a 30% hike, it's closed with minimal hike with existing employees. It excites employees initially but not good for a longer run. 
No benefits, in terms of bonus, etc. For the brand JPMC is and the kind of revenue being made you can do something good for your people.
New hires from other small companies pollute the atmosphere at JPMC in terms of professionalism especially hiring at the management level. I don't understand why the business hires such people who lack basic ethics that kinda ruins the image JPMC has.

headline: NO Hike in the first appraisal cycle if you join after June
pros: Good perks & benefits than many other banks.
cons:
Pathetic Indian managers/ directors. HR/policy says you are eligible to get hike in your first appraisal cycle if you joined before October, but managers has their own hidden policy book, which says NO Hike if you joined after June. 

I would request HR recruitment team to update their policy accordingly and do not do fake commitment to the candidates.

Long working hours, which is okay sometimes. But intentionally scheduling calls beyond working hours, is not okay.

headline: They tell you you're doing one thing, and you end up doing another
pros: It's client facing, and at least you can do some maintenance on customers' accounts. I love helping clients in that respect.
cons: I was told I wouldn't be spending too much time on the teller side, when literally I guess Chase is making associate BANKERS be tellers from now on. I left my job at BofA as a teller there to come here and be a "banker" and open accounts, which they told me I would be during the interview (just with not as much access as the RBs), and I'm relegated to be a teller. So, Chase basically lied.

headline: Good work life balance, benefits, job security. Needs better comp
pros:

- Work life balance, only expect 40 hours per week of employees
- Job security, only 1 person I worked with was ever let go during my 3 years here
- Internal mobility, many open jobs internally for changing teams
- Good benefits
cons:
- Climbing the corporate ladder can be difficult here, generally takes time but working harder or more won't necessarily get you noticed
- Compensation could be better, I ended up leaving for a 50% salary increase at a different company. They will only really raise your salary significantly if you make it known you are looking to leave by having other job offers
- They will also hire new employees with less experience at a higher salary than you

headline: Good company for early career
pros: Good company for fresh graduates to gain experience. The company's culture, diversity, inclusion is competitive in industry. The benefits are competitive as well.
cons:
The compensation is low comparing with competitors and it's hard to get a fair salary increase by moving internally. Top performer could also be the one who make least money in the team. The salary gap within the same team could be very large depending on your starting salary with the firm, internal vs. external employees, etc. For example, employees who start as Teller or Contractors who make $14/hour will be at the lowest range in 10 years if they later move into higher value corporate functions. One could make $60K vs. peers $120K, while performing better than others.

JPMC encourage mobility but it's not a real mobility. It's easy to move internally doing the same thing with little or no salary increase and no career advancements. The valuable and well-paid positions are highly competitive and a lot of these positions are external hires or Investment Banking positions (Hiring Ivy graduates). There is little or no chance for loyal internal employees who work in JPMC for 5 or 10 years. Even if experience and qualifications meet the job requirement, it could be harder than going to the moon.

The management has problems. When the team lost US employees, management hire offshore teams to re-fill. The offshore team is larger than US team in one of my roles in JPMC. 

The senior management needs to figure out where the budget was spent.
Management makes top money but some associate-level employees spent years with JPMC are not even making as much as entry-level employees.
Myself start with a ground level job in JPMC making as much as a cashier, when I move into higher value teams, my pay never go up that much to stay competitive with my peers or industry average, I am always the lowest range no matter where I move internally, even though my education and certifications, experience and work attitude are superior. The good reviews could mean nothing. I accepted a better external opportunity offer me 60% increase in salary. I also have a co-worker got his salary doubled. This is not rare at all. In my opinion, by no means this could happen.

headline: Please go to somewhere else if you are really into technology
pros: It is still a big brand to be listed on your CV.
cons: Tons of red tapes, for example you have to write an essay before doing deployment to production, or go through tedious process that requires the approval of senior management (who might not have coded in the recent 5 years) before real work of onboarding some new features can be done. You can only deploy to production during nighttime (regular overtime basically), and the process is quite manual too. You are also expected to provide production support on a rotational basis, even on a public holiday! With this you get to witness how fragile the various systems can be on production. Code quality is questionable, once in a while you'll see code without any unit test, and the original authors are all gone, nobody dares to touch those files. The codebase also has nonexistent or outdated documentation. Most importantly the compensation is peanut, which doesn't help improve the retention rate, the firm's strategy to this is to outsource more and more of the software development to cheaper regions.

headline: I personally feel a huge sense of pride when I say that I work for JP Morgan
pros:
I have an MBA and part of a Process Improvement Team. So I cannot speak for folks in the operations or technology side of the company. So here are the pros:
1. Great people to work with and learn from.
2. Very inclusive culture. They have an Employee Appreciation Week every year.
3. Flexible with respect to work timings.
4. If you deserve a promotion, they will give it to you.
5. Great exposure as I get to interact with folks who are the beneficiaries of the work I do.
6. Faster growth in terms of learnings you get from the work.
7. Good job satisfaction
8. You even get an additional CEO bonus if the bank has done well in the year which is almost everytime.
cons:
1. Financial growth is at a slower rate as compared to competitors.
2. They stopped giving gifts as part of new policy.

headline: Good Compentation but very bad US couterparts

3) New ideas and thoughts are never appreciated, just follow what the US counterparts want us to do, even if it means rework and duplicate work

headline: Women first culture while Men get marginalised unless you bootlick
pros: You are really just working for the brand name. The Compensation is not competitive.
cons:
Increasingly you might realise the company has a “woman-first” culture. If there are two equally capable candidates who are top performers, the female will be promoted first. This is very prevalent in internal mobility situations as well where you might realise in the top jobs, female candidates only require to meet the minimum criteria for the role to be accepted while males will be required to overcompensate for the same role to be moved forward. This is only for Analyst/Associate positions which generally is very still very junior. If females were in this position, they would be complaining that there is no gender equality. On this end, there must be controls to protect both females and males equality chances and not just conforming to social pressures to blindly give opportunities and chances to female candidates first.

For males to succeed in the company you probably need to bootlick well and play politics right to get promoted. I had a co-worker who was really close to my manager, didn’t contribute anything to the BAU tasks but was promoted twice in 2 years. They were so close such that even the spouse were friends with him. Clearly the promotion came from favouritism perspective.

Pay is not competitive and the firm is not trying to keep you. You will realise this once you start going for interviews for the same role.

headline: Working as a VP/BA in JP Morgan
pros:
1. A large organization with many different opportunities.
2. Well-established tech infrastructure so you dont have to worry about getting a server set up, a database provisioned, subscribing to market data or reference data. You can focus on the business function deliveries.
3. People are generally quite respectful.
cons:
1. Pay is not high. Bonus in tech team is quite little.

headline: Might be a good fit if this is what you are looking for
pros:
- You can internally move to another team, and the entire company encourages to do so.
- You work in a big banking player.
cons:
- If you work in Tech, you'll note there's a huge gap between your salary and Business. I worked in the company several years, and it's common to see 3x / 4x bigger bonuses on the Business side.
- The promotion process is completely broken. If you start in one of the programs focused on getting newly graduates to the firm, it will take you 2 years to advance to 601 (Associate), even to 602 (senior Associate) if you have a good performance. However, Getting to 603 is incredibly hard. You need to get very important sponsors (ED, MD level) and they need to build your case in a very good way. You can find 602s coming out from college with 2 years of experience, but also people with 10-15 years experience, waiting to get a promotion.
I've been in teams where the common word was "it's normal not to get the promotion the first year you postulate for it".

headline: Horrible horrible and horrible
pros: Don't have anything to add here
cons: The most terrible experience with this company. I was invited for the first steps in August, passed it with recruiter and then with hiring managers. After they contacted and said they loved my skills and everything but they will not open the position. After some weeks they contacted me again and they said they will reopen the position. I was invited to next steps. I had a call with vice-president and before that I was told after this round I will have last round however this lady in the interview told I will have another interview with the person from their team which was additional. They contacted me that they will arrange it as soon as possible bur after 10 days still nothing. I wrote them email and thanking them for the recruitment cause I didn't want to move on with them anymore after this horrible unprofessional approach and they didn't even email me back anything. Totally screwed up

- Managers here are people with expert knowledge of the product but zero project management skills and interpersonal skills
- Most existing team members would not share the knowledge with any new members to get the job done as the knowledge is now their personel asset

- Somewhat toxic work environment in some projects

headline: Community Cousins Rule with total disregard to talent
pros: If you donot know anything in technology you will make directors and managing director in this firm
cons:
Interviews are conducted for cousins and relatives for telugu and hindi people and selected 100% of the time without neither merit nor talent
Furthermore, interviews are conducted in telugu or hindu based on the language comfort of the particular if your vocabulary skills are good you are select
There are plenty of incidents where telugu and hindi people receive kick backs for full time and contractor.
JPMorgan also has offices in hyderabad and mumbai where business calls happen in hindi and telugu, if you are an american god help you. There is no talent in this rut.

headline: Underpaid like cheap laborers.
pros: Benefits, Brand, Healthcare & nothing else.
cons: JP Morgan is just a brand to be honest in terms of pay. At India employees are under paid, under skilled, overloaded with work. Employees who have been working for years are highly underpaid, worse than a tea seller (this is not an exaggeration) you can Google the attrition rate and the reason. During yearly appraisals the management an HR state you've got the best hike which is 5-7% and trust me everyone's heard this. HR is always hand in hand with the management with fake concern and indirectly try to scare you over if you continue to escalate your career will be affected. Very little support for skill enhancement and trainings. No work flexibility, no wfh option. Politics and bootlicking culture @AWM Testing team under ED Pankaja Pathak.

headline: Impressive Rotational Analyst Program
author_position: Global Finance and Business Management Analyst
pros:
The GF&BM (Global Finance & Business Management) rotational program offers three different positions (one during internship, then first and second rotations) across finance and accounting roles -- which is helpful in gaining a range of experience in the financial services industry

I appreciated the formal feedback process that took place 2x each rotation, mid-way through and at the end of the role
cons:
While we were asked to submit our preferences for positions and sectors within the bank that we would like to work, the preferences are only taken into consideration to a certain extent. As expected, the business needs are the highest priority.

Management is hit or miss. I had one manager who I really respected and enjoyed working for, and another who drove me out of the company because I found them intolerable. Most employees are pretty pleasant to work with though, in my experience.

As of 2021, the compensation of this program is also not as competitive as I would expect.

headline: Great job!
pros: I really enjoyed my time at Chase Bank as Part time teller. We were given plenty of training, a clothing amount to pick out our own shirts, and before I had to quit to move out of state we got a great pay bump. Paid days off were nice as well if you get sick.
cons:
Customers aren't as nice as I thought they'd be when you're there to help them. 
Having to change my password CONSTANLY to something I've never used and having to remember it haha.
I HATED having to write my own annual review!

pros: Leading financial institution and a brand. Good 401K match, 20 paid vacation, training and learning opportunities. (Don't fall for these benefits. Every other good company has these benefits.)
cons: Not easy to navigate/find opportunities for growth, no salary increments, lots of bureaucracy and politics. Technology maturity needed to execute ambitious complex and large programs with in-house teams is extremely poor(Lot of hyped geniuses here). Heavy reliance on Consultants and Consulting firms to steer the ship. Stay away from working in a bank if you are a smart aspiring software engineer/tech lead/solution architect. I would prefer a top tier Technology service/consulting firm or a tech company over a bank.

headline: Industry Leader On The Border of Complacency
pros:
-All the great things about working for an industry leading company (great vacation, decent 401k match, stock buying program for employees, decent healthcare benefits)
-Management walks the walk when caring about their employees / building a solid culture (work life balance is solid, plenty of team building exercises)
-Collaborative environment that makes problem solving fun
cons:
-Being a massive company there are a lot of communication gaps leading to issues in execution (e.g. lines of business not talking to each other) which is frustrating to work to clean up / can lead to burnout
-Company feels stuck in it's ways / not adaptable (e.g. large focus to get people back into the office instead of looking at what flex work could look like for the workforce)
-Company talks about focusing on the customer experience but focuses more on the bottom line when it comes down to brass tax

headline: Good Company
pros: Pay, benefits, bonus, opportunity,technology are all good. I want to be clear I think Chase is a great place to work.  The people are amazing, the culture is real. I'm just writing my honest review. I have leared so much in my role in only 3 years. Bonuses were good also between 18K-60K per year for BM.
cons:
This is a high sales job, always focused on selling products to clients. It's called the One Chase. Selling, Credit Cards, Investments, Home Lending. Branch staff has been cut over the years. Staffing depends on branch location, some branches have 3 people, while others have 5-9 people. 

Technology is changing in the branches about 90% of what we do in the branches can be done online or over the phone. With this increased changes banking will continue to become more digital. You will spend a lot of time on the phone calling and emailing clients. I would say opportunity depends on the location you work. Each location has One Chase Partners; however, they tend to focus on busier location compared to other locations. Your bankers will be hit or miss depending on the branch. Most of my time as BM was spent helping coach bankers, calling banker support, or doing operations work needed in the branch. Some days are slow, some are busy depends on the day of the week. Your bankers have to call about 60-100 people per week in addition to meetings. As mention you will spend a lot of time on the phone. 
The only reason I left was because I think banking is changing, everything will look different in the future. So much of our job can be done online. Promotions depend on your MD signing off. Some people get promoted multiple times a year while others have to wait. Market Directors need to be more visible in markets (Branches). Be consistent around treatment of all employees.

headline: Some Good People, some not so good people
pros: Good starting hourly pay, decent benefits, easy overall work. You can just turn your brain most of the way off and listen to whatever you like on an appropriate MP3 player. Employment is about to be contingent on full vaccination, finally.
cons: Constantly changing (not that change is bad mind, just is when the changes are bad in of themselves or prioritized badly), badly designed program used for keying. Management will constantly pretend that they care about your feedback. Weird hours (for now?), four ten hour work days or nights. Current (November 2021) expansion construction is disruptive.

headline: Credit departement in Geneva
pros: Very good name on the CV for future jobs
cons:
Many, among: 
- Salary is terrible (close to the minimum wage in Geneva applicable in 2021) and they can only attract people from abroad with zero knowledge of the Swiss Labour Market
- Bonus is ridiculous (0k-2kCHF gross) for an analyst
- No meritocracy. It's all about nepotism, eventually gender/nationality. Consequently, the internal mobility is inexistant. This is a shame.
- Tasks are extremely divided among teams so you learn almost nothing
 - General credit/risk/finance understanding of people is very poor due to recruitment practices (<10% of employees have a university degree and a background in finance)

headline: LHI needs to be re-evaluate EOAs
pros: Warner Brothers itself is a great company to work for BUT
cons: The RNs hired by LHI are severely mistreated by EOAs . Working conditions were deplorable. So many nurses quit because the temperature in the tent was 102 degrees most of the time and nurses were covered in extensive PPE and not allowed an air conditioner or a bottle of water, which made them sick and forced them to resign. The EOA did nothing to accommodate the nurses and in fact laughed at their requests, even though some were exposed to dangerous sun rays. This individual thought production was stealing her paper towels and nurses were degraded and forced to sign out paper towels. So absurd!! She was suspicious of everyone. Very difficult to be working around her. I have 2 degrees from UCLA and this was an all time low. I worked on movie set as a set nurse all the way back to 1970 and I was treated very well and paid very well .....things have changed with these EOAs. They need to return to school and learn about infection control and how to treat other human beings.

headline: Large big bank that treats employees like cogs.
pros:
Good first job
Stable pay
Expectations of responsibilities are typically clear
cons:
Overworked for relatively low pay compared to industry peers
Preach a meritocracy but don’t back it up at all
Top down decisions that arent clearly thought out about how they impact lower level employees

headline: Worst experience of my life
pros:
- strong salary, some bonus, benefits
- some expert colleagues
- theoretical possibility of internal mobility
- some interesting projects
cons:
- toxic work environment (bullying, gaslighting, gossip, passive aggressive hostility)
- no mentorship whatsoever
- public harassment and abuse, being yelled at in an open office
- line manager knows he is protected by the company and HR and abuses his reports, constant violation of the "Code of Conduct"
- diversity and inclusion initiative turned upside down where ethnic minorities and women become most likely to get abused on a daily basis
- stack ranking pitting team members against each other contributing to toxicity
- zero collaborative spirit due to above
- a ton of line managers without any relevant technological skills
- heavy politics, favoritism, nepotism
- all about the perception/image, not about tech skills and who does good work
- horrible work life balance with a lot of unpaid overtime on most of the projects
- mostly very boring work
- horrible internal technology and tools (Athena)
- cannot install any software tool or library without weeks of waiting on approval, resulting in just not installing and "doing it ourselves"
- some of the most valuable development resources (GitHub) blocked from visiting
- incredibly bureaucratic in general
- tech personnel second-class citizens to bankers

headline: Best company I have ever worked for

headline: Great working enviornment and improving, but...

cons: Pay rate for experienced workers is falling well behind the industry standard which is causing a massive exodus, promotion criteria more confusing than before and not nearly as transparent as it is portrayed to be. Strong push to return to office due to real estate pricing reasons rather than productivity reasons.

headline: Buisness first, tech second
pros:
Usually a good work life balance but depends on the LOB. 
WFH half the time - should be less IMO.
Pay is alright and usually scales with cost of living. Once you're in, you're in and it can be a cushy job for many.
The 'fun' is really dependent on what you are doing, it's fintech so it can get ugly but it can also be super cool AI/ML.
You can get into some cloud projects as well.
cons:
Upper management is afraid to get their hands dirty. They push for things without telling the underlings their goal, nor get their feedback on the feasibility. They only understand the projects at a surface level.
 
Nobody helps each other or does the bare minimum. 

As a result I feel like Soviet Russia where people say "everything is fine" yet no progress is being made. There is a lot of obscurity between upper management and their engineers.

Even lower management is locked into endless meetings meaning they can never actually check in at a granular level.

headline: Mixed Bag
pros:
- Great health insurance and other benefits
- Better than average 401K match
- Amazing amount of paid time off
- Annual 'gift' to 401K which is a percentage of your salary
cons:
- This entirely depends on what department you are in, but my department has absolutely no room to grow. You are stuck in your role with minimal raises despite stellar performance reviews. 
- The company has great benefits but is cheap in every other way it can possibly be. Will not pay more despite gaining additional licenses for your role. 
- Management does not seem to understand the very responsibilities they are tasked with managing.
- This is probably due to the benefits, but much lower than expected salary for the work and licensing.

headline: Good place to build book of business.
pros: JP Morgan-Chase will give you a great opportunity to build a book of business. If you can work well with the branch team you will be successful in building a solid client base. You do not need to call friends and family to start your business here. The 401k match is solid too.
cons: Covid-19 has made it more difficult to close business. Less people are coming into the branches. JP Morgan has a very aggressive compliance department. They will be looking into every deal that you close. This is a difficult business as it is. Having a compliance department breathing down your neck while you are trying to build revenue for the bank is not a good environment.

headline: Boring
pros:
Safe and easy job
Base of 42k and guaranteed bonus of $1500/month for the 1st year

This is a great job for someone out of college. Not if your seasoned.
cons:
If your looking for a boring but easy job. Want to sit in a bank all day and open up checking accounts and credit cards. This is your job. It’s not much opportunity to move up alp though they will say u can move into multiple rolls from the banking side. There is no structure to actually obtain these roles. Well at least in the Atlanta’s market.
You won’t make a base more than 42k. Realistically your monthly bonuses is around $1000-$1200.
They want you to be the assistant to financial advisors. And do all the work to get them clients. They don’t tell u this in the interview
They also want u to make 40 calls a day which is pointless becAuse u can’t talk investments even if your licensed
Long banking hours suck

headline: Terrible.
pros:
Pay is alright. 
Benefits are good, the insurance is trash though.
cons:
Constantly messing up my pay. 
Health insurance pays literally nothing until you've met your deductible, and then only does reimbursement, so you're still paying out of pocket for everything up front. And then if you're lucky, Aetna will mail you a check. It's nearly impossible to keep track of what's owed where with how their insurance works. 
Managers have no idea what's going on. Go months at a time without coaching or development. 
Customers are generally upper-middle class and awful. Metric goals aren't clearly communicated and you're not given tools and training to be successful. 
There is an actual policy for how to handle a customer holding you hostage on the phone. 
Currently on a short-term disability leave and should be receiving 60% of my pay. But they can't figure it out so I'm actually receiving closed to 40% pay and missing pay for almost an entire pay cycle, after not being paid in 3 weeks. Last time, I went 5 weeks without being paid. They've also shorted me for 2+ months on shift differential. 
Largest bank in the world and they can't manage their finances for their employees. I imagine they're probably ripping off thousands of employees pay, and I bet it just slides under the radar.

headline: Good bank to work at
pros: Compensation is very good. $18.50 seems like a little but that's the floor for RBs. Once you're out of training and on the floor, you will make a minimum of $1000 at the end of every month if you don't meet your sales goal. You have the opportunity to earn 2x-3x the amount of your monthly paychecks off bonuses alone but its entirely dependent on the RB and their work ethic.
cons: Very old technology given to employees

headline: Great Benefits
pros: Great benefits, 401K ,vacation time, health insurance.
cons: Very stressful environment. Coaching given is more to get a write-up than coaching. Performance goals are crazy. My vehicle was stolen from the parking lot and security was not willing to cooperate in providing any video or information from outside cameras. Company basically said that because Security company was a third party they couldn't really do anything about their non-willingness to help. I guess the video cameras are only for show. On weekends there was always people loitering in the parking lot.

headline: Big name, big management issues
pros: Pays well, ample time off, great name on resume.
cons: Work life balance sucks. It’s not uncommon for people try to put meetings on your calendars after hours. Also there’s a ton of bureaucracy. Political landmines everywhere. Zero process management in DCE. Every single team does everything differently and people are turned into managers based off of nepotism (blatant at that) instead of actual merit. Also Chase is handling COVID extremely irresponsibly. Senior management basically threatened us with full time return to the office if we don’t comply with this hybrid schedule. Folks are exiting at a high rate and it’s very telling. Not a diverse culture at all and I’m in the NY office.

headline: Good job stability/security but red tape, old-school corporate culture, and questionable pay
pros:
- Good job stability; there's always work that needs to be done
- Very strong company (Industry leader)
- Get to work on projects that impact the global economy at both macro and micro level (e.g. retail and wholesale technologies)
cons:
- Stressful environment driven by deadlines instead of actual capacity, budgeting, resources, people
- They don't keep up with the market rate of salary growth or reward backend technologies with compensation (especially if you stay too long)
- Slow pace of change due to bureaucracy 
- The usual cons of banking corporations: you're just a number/resource, lot of red tape/policies that restrict personal and salary growth, old-school culture and mentality.

headline: Mediocre middle management, bureaucracy
pros: It's a place to make a decent salary for a couple of years
cons:
- The people you want to work with will leave for better companies or teams.
- Mobility is very poor and limited to roles similar to what you're in, not what you're qualified for. There are active policies in place at the firm that perpetuate this.
- Once you come in at a certain pay, you're stuck, it will never increase and possibly even decrease!
- Promotions and growth seem to be completely based on headcount managed (and with no qualitative contribution to that headcount even!) rather than any true contribution to the company.

headline: My Review on working at JP Morgan
pros:
Work life balance
Good networking opportunities
Great learning opportunities
Wide variety of events to gain knowledge, have fun and help in growth
cons:
After working for an year at JP Morgan I feel that your experience mostly depends on the team you are assigned to. Be it learning, development etc.... But we do get an opportunity to explore various hackathons.
Also, the package offered to IITians is on a different level compared to NITians, but there is no difference between the packages offered to NITians and other regional engineering colleges.

headline: Toxic work culture
pros:
Pay is market for recruiters 
It's easier to recruit top candidates when you have this great brand standing behind you
Hiring managers are heavily involved with networking and helping to build pipelines
Good benefits
cons:
Extremely long hours - very heavy req load 35+ reqs. 
Minimal work/life balance.
A ton of PTO days but still expected to work 
Hiring managers are extremely demanding 
Toxic work environment - management allows team members and hiring managers to borderline verbally abuse you in the workplace
Dog eat dog environment - if you can't keep up with the heavy work load and constant demand of hiring managers you are ostracized.
It's a great company for recruiters who don't value their work/life balance, want to be working 15 hours a day and always on call.

headline: Nice people, challenging work, endless career opportunities

I worked at Chase 5 years and loved it. It is a large company so there are plenty of career mobility opportunities. The people are super nice and caring.
The technology (which is area I worked in) is undergoing major changes which are forward thinking.
cons: A bit bureaucratic (it's big!). Sometimes it takes a long time to get things done.

headline: Difficulty to keep talent
pros: This is a big bank so there is a lot of variety in the types of roles and it's possible to change teams internally without too much risk.
cons: As a big bank, they are struggling to keep talent so you may end up working with people that are pretty average.

headline: Great company to work for…
pros:
Great company to work for. Spent 10 years as employee. started my career as Associate and went all the up to ED in IC Path.

+ career Management For both who want to explore IC role in Technical space or want to explore in management side.
+ Open Culture and no hierarchy management. You can reach out to anyone.
+ Rewards & Recognition
+ Management is very strong, if you are will to take challenges, then management is going to support you 100%
+ Management encourages you to take add on responsibilities and drive changes in the Organization.
+ problem solving @ scale. There is no comparison of this sort of scale in any organization.

headline: Profitable company with unhappy employees
pros:
1. If you want to apply your knowledge and skills to develop something good then this the place.
2. Amazing L&D team. They provide some really good resources for learning, different communities share their knowledge and it's amazing!
3. Good transport facilities.
4. Thanks to pandemic, they allowed wfh now. Saved travelling time.
5. Culture of innovation and sharing.
6. 360 feedback. It does make an impact!
cons:
1. Compensation is below market standards for existing employees. 
2. Company is hiring less experienced resources at higher pay and higher grade for the same project. This is very demotivating!
3. Pay well to shared resources. They fill-up multiple positions and must be compensated accordingly.
4. No work life balance. Though higher management was vocal about relaxing work pressure, local managers never cared for it. Almost worked 11-12 hrs daily every week.
5. Global mobility is just on papers. Global managers reject candidates because it requires approval from higher management and other regulatory clearances which no manager wants to get involved in it.

headline: Does not care about the welfare of employees
pros: I think I got very lucky with the team and manager I had. They were great and the work life balance was great. I really got to learn a lot as this was my first job out of college. All of this growth is def attributed to the great manager I had.
cons:
They really don't care about you as an employee. Working in tech I was expecting to work from home until it was 100% safe to return. We've been working remotely since March 2020 and we've kept the company running. 
They rewarded us by cutting pay raises while the company had record profits.

They made us return to work with a flex hybrid model and they aren't mandating vaccines for employees returning. I don't feel safe at work. I have people on my team that are anti-vax and I'm still expected to return to work and interact with them. With the rising delta cases I expected us to return to full time work form home, but management has just doubled down instead and they expect us all to wear masks now at work.

They know they will be losing talent due to the return to office plan and they are ok with. Management has stated they are ok with the expected attrition. They don't value domain level knowledge at all.

headline: Management has lost its way / major compensation issues
pros: JP Morgan is a great place to start your career -- the training programs are excellent and they make a significant investment in developing junior talent.
cons: I spent over 10 years at the firm and the first half of my time was great. The firm develops junior talent and the culture of the firm used to be stronger. Over the last few years, management has lost its way. During the pandemic -- a time of record profits -- the firm pulled back on resources and bankers burned out. Following a string of high level Private Bank departures, the bank is now trying to course correct. Banker compensation is also way under market and there is absolutely no transparency year-over-year into what you will make. There is very little correlation between results and pay -- it has more to do with management discretion. There is way too much importance placed on "managers" in the Private Bank -- the result is micromanagement instead of arming bankers with the tools they need to bring in business.

headline: Working in HR at JPMC
pros:
Controls focus, there is respect given to risk and controls in the organization
People are generally pleasant to work with and get the job done
Connectivity globally is decent - for its size, communication flow is reasonably good
cons:
Culture can be passive-aggressive though people are supposed to be "nice"
People are smart but definitely not the brightest in the industry
Cultural differences between the different LOBs - AWM vs. CIB are very different; Corp Functions again very different. From a support angle, CIB should really be getting the bulk of support and resources given their share of PnL but AWM is much better resourced and supported than the CIB

headline: Great company

headline: Wholesale Payments
pros:
- excellent brand name
- strong training programs with growth opportunities in many teams
- motivated and intelligent co-workers and mentors
- lots of opportunities to learn
- tuition reimbursement ($7500 per year)
cons:
- mobility within the firm doesn't really exist even though management/HR/recruiters tells you it does; it's much easier to move to another similar group externally than internally
- management handled COVID-19 poorly; there's also a blatant disregard for employees' well-being (everyone wants to work for JPM, so management treats employees like they're disposable... because they are)
- the firm only really cares about it's top tier / highest paid groups e.g., investment banking, second tier and lower don't have much of a voice, even though they still have plenty of talent and add a lot of value
- the firm makes hiring decisions based on skin color, sex, etc. rather than meritocratic qualities e.g., have to interview 2 males, 2 females regardless of the demographics of the applicant pool

headline: They don't care about tech
pros: If you are an employee then you're treated fairly well.
cons:
The business does not listen to technology people. My team became more productive during the 2020 work from home. And the 2021 kerfuffle and lack of planning only caused stress among the tech staff - dates/times for return to office changed on a whim. 

What really gets me is how management DOES NOT CARE about you. Many people rightfully complained that it is difficult to schedule their lives around a constantly changing return to office schedule. And instead of doing anything, there was a mass email basicallh saying 'thanks for complaining, deal with the stress and stop bothering us'.

Cultural stuff - I was on a line of business call with our leaders and found out the hard way that they really do not care about mental health or the LGBTQ+ community. I brought up the fact that several mental health conditions would cause people to struggle with a rotating office schedule and a fixed one would be better. I was hoping for either the fixed schedule or a recommendation to use an internal mental health source - at least lip service. Instead I was told that everyone has to deal with their own problems and find your own help. Took until after I put in my 2 week notice and were hemorrhaging tech talent till they actually gave people mental health resources to help transition out of the pandemic.

Also, if you are a contractor you are at best a second class citizen.

headline: review PCA
pros: The bank can be a great pipeline feeder depending on Bankers experience. In additional having the bank can be a huge plus for clients. Lots of autonomy to build out your day. Tremendous access to critical research and calls.
cons:
Huge lack of sales training and prep for bankers new and old. This then leaves it to branch partners (HLA's, Advisors and business relationship managers) to teach sales training to Bankers. In addition many bankers are hired without really understanding that they are in a sales role which leads to confusion and comfortability and ultimately higher turnover.
Lastly, as much as having the bank as a plus for clients it can also be the reason you loose clients. If your clients are looking for local credit union flexibility you will not find it here.

headline: Nothing to brag about
pros:
Flexible with days and time off
Decent amount of paid time off
Nice coworkers
cons:
Benefits are not great considering that it’s one of the biggest banks in the world
This particular department is clicky and you can’t get promoted unless you’re golfing with one of the higher ups on weekends, a good friend or a family member
Upper management are arrogant  liars and not sincere and give you the run around and no straight answer to anything regarding promos and org changes. They make it like they care about your future and job but they clearly don’t
Constant nagging over your numbers and how much work you submit. They Preach quality is more important than quantity than micromanage and whine if you submit  a low number for a day
Upper management is clueless on how much work they dump on us daily 
Your day is never an 8 hour day and they expect you to work later hours when we are salaried and don’t get OT
Grossly underpaid, we basically get paid lower just to work for the name 
The office is lame. We have no drawers and they expect us to lug all of our stuff back and forth to the office when most of us have an hour or longer commute on the train and subway
Org changes are immediate with no warning such as demoting a bunch of people to consolidate the department

headline: Tools available to you work against you
pros:
Semi competitive benefits.
Room for growth.
Large teams, so lots of expertise if you can find it.
cons:
The development environments available to do your job are by far the worst I have ever used in my life. You are denied basic permissions such as deleting desktop icons and everything you need to access is on internal resources that fail to load the first few times.

They started me off on a Windows 7 VM and eventually gave me a Windows 10 VM but in order to use the Windows 10 VM you had to open it through the Windows 7 VM... can't make this stuff up. The Win10 environment ended up being useless because, despite the sub company I work for being part of JPM Chase, it still has a separate domain that the new environment didn't have access to. So every dev on my team, set up this new environment just to find out it was not usable and go back to our derelict Win7 setups.

They force internal tooling on you for installing needed applications such as Postman and offer no support when things don't work. My helpdesk tickets are often auto-closed and tagged with comments completely irrelevant to the issue forcing me to re-open then. When a ticket it finally picked up by a person, weeks later, they usually also immediately close it and tell you that can't do anything about it.

All in all, it's astounding that anyone gets any work done in this environment and, truthfully, quite a number of the developers I work with don't. They are forever just reporting blockers at the daily scrum. So they through even more developers at the project who are, in turn, constantly working against the very tools we are handed to do the job.

headline: Incredibly Toxic Working Environment. The Very Worst of American Corporate Culture
pros: None at all if I’m brutally honest. Name on the CV I guess.
cons:
Where to begin…The most toxic working environment I have ever worked in.

1: Very Hierarchical. People, especially newly promoted VPs like to broadcast their status in the pecking order. If you spend too long at Analyst or Associate (over 3 years) nobody will respect you.

2: Promotion process past Associate very opaque. If you’re stuck in certain roles, good luck getting promoted further as it won’t happen. Management want certain people to stay where they are as they can't be bothered to train people up to do their roles. Also, Management are unwilling to change the scope of roles to allow you to progress.

3: Talk a good game about mobility, but in reality, very difficult to move to a better role. Management often  refuse to engage in conversations about career development, if the desire for development takes you out of the area you are working in.

4: Very easy to get stuck in a dead end role and get pigeonholed.

5: Senior Management in Operations treat us like children.

6: Keep banging on about Diversity, Culture of Respect training etc, however this doesn’t filter down to individual teams. Personally seen so many examples of bullying, racist and xenophobic comments, ableism etc which in any normal company would lead the perpetrators to be sacked. Been on the receiving end of a number comments and actions that would be considered bullying. Was personally told by a previous manager not to escalate a number of incidents I was on the receiving end of to HR as "there's a very high threshold for what the firm considers as workplace bullying"

7: Management favourites are protected. Double Standards seemed to be applied daily.

8: Incredibly Bureaucratic. Very onerous controls environment for no reason. Obsession with reducing costs

9: Pay progression is below market value. Can often experience a real terms pay cut if your salary increase is below rate of inflation. Pitiful bonuses in Operations which seem to get smaller and smaller every year.

10: Work-Life balance is for Management and Management favourites only.

11: Feels like the firm is rushing back to normal because the CEO doesn’t like work from home, and there are plenty of Middle Managers who love to micromanage and control their minions. Work from Home has arguably kept me at the firm for at least a year longer than I wanted. 

12: You are ostracised if you refuse to acquiesce to the culture and drink the “kool aid”.  Colleagues love to be nosey in your personal life and criticise you if you don’t follow their way to live your life. If you stand up to people like this here, they quickly become vindictive and encourage other people put in spurious complaints against you.

headline: Low pay, micro managed
pros: Only pro is if you like low pay, new employees getting paid higher than you with less experience or even licensing. You like to be micromanaged and like working for a company that doesn’t support you when coworkers are sexually harassing you or bullying you. The only pro is that the branch manager got fired but was after I left.
cons: Low pay, low commissions, unreasonable expectations. All the training is about ethics and integrity but when you get into the branch they want you to open bank accounts and credit cards without the clients consent. It’s all about the numbers and nothing about customer service and building trust and relationships.

headline: Not the company it once was

•Decent vacation package 
•Pension (No longer offered to new employees)
•MRA funds

•Base pay is low and about half of what you can get at other banks 
•Commissions are cut yearly to make sure bankers work like animals to meet sales goals
•Constantly overworked and understaffed
•Bad morale throughout company…many bankers interviewing and planning to leave to competitors
•30 minute lunch
•Doors never closed during COVID and company risked the lives of employees while other banks protected their staff
•Bankers are expected to be telemarketers and call the same clients over and over

headline: Shift in management, shift in employee morale
pros: you get to work with people from different backgrounds and all aspects of life, you see the needs and changes of the community if you're there long enough, and you make meaningful connections with coworkers and clients
cons: Unfortunately with the shift in management and technology, it has become the micromanagement of the ones who are running the operation and the most disconnected from the people we were meant to serve. We try to cater to everyone, but when they cut the incentives to only pay us out when we serve to only the rich, bankers will know what to not waste time on. I hope bankers don't cherry pick so they help only the people who have money or wealth, but when we open anything other than a mortgage or investment, we don't get paid for our efforts, dis-incentivizing bankers from doing the simplest, yet time consuming things, because its not in the interest of our paycheck.

headline: Prioritizes employees and embraces a growth mindset...
pros: J.P. Morgan embraces a growth mindset and offer many paths to help you develop your skills and promote career mobility. During the pandemic, they also took the necessary steps to keep employees safe and where hiring at a time when many companies were laying off.
cons: Many employees wish to continue working remote, however, there is a push from senior leaders for everyone to return to the office. J.P.Morgan could do a better job recognizing the cultural shift that took place because of the pandemic. During the pandemic, we've proven our ability to adapt and are even more productive than before. Many employees recognize the benefit and use the reclaimed commute time to spend with our families or complete work tasks. J.P.Morgan launched initiatives to be more green and forcing all employees back to the office conflicts with those priorities. The added expense to employees and the increase in emissions and wear and tear (e.g., tires) is inconsistent with going green.

headline: Young white men not welcome
pros:
By the time you leave, you will have developed an unparalleled level of personal resilience due to the toxic management culture.

And if you don’t leave, you’ll be blissfully ignorant of your Stockholm Syndrome and buy into the subliminal message that you should be happy to work for the biggest bank in the world.
cons:
The Diversity and Inclusion narrative comes across as disingenuous. You have a bunch of white billionaires attempting to show that they understand what is actually going on in the world and simply react to the topic du jour. There is no real strategy, only action for the sake of saying something about a topic.

There is a constant barrage of US-focussed messaging that is disenfranchising for international colleagues and creates an obvious sense of “them and us”.

Operating Committee members are openly stating that they are giving their MDs targets linked to Diversity and Inclusion. This can be loosely translated to “quotas” based on racial and gender profiling. This effectively makes it a hostile environment for young white men and there have been many examples of people feeling forced to share their harrowing backgrounds and difficult stories in an attempt to fit into the narrative and prove that they’re not just some privileged white guy.

The general management style of ED+ is transactional and focussed on execution. A really good example of this comes from the very top: "We want people back to work, and my view is that sometime in September, October it will look just like it did before," Dimon said at The Wall Street Journal CEO Council. "And everyone is going to be happy with it, and yes, the commute, you know people don't like commuting, but so what."

This general disdain for staff percolates through the executive, senior and middle management levels. Middle managers often demonstrates elements of coercive control and psychological abuse through a pattern of manipulative behaviours and exerting power over a direct report, often through intimidation or humiliation.

The culture, particularly with the CIB, is toxic. Narcissistic behaviour is encouraged and rewarded.

You will rapidly go from earning more than your peers to being the lowest earner in your peer group. The compensation practices are designed to align you to the prevailing rate of inflation, regardless of your performance. There is a huge amount of secrecy around pay band by title, but it is easy enough to discover. When you get promoted, you will be given the title but not the compensation and will spend the following years just trying to scrape into the lower end of the range.

headline: Mixed bag
pros:
1 - Good chance of internal mobility, Company doing well
2 - Can add good brand name on your CV
3 - They love to promote diversity (mostly for PR reasons). This could be a great place for the women.
cons:
1 - The QR Mumbai team has a bit political environment. Variable, promotion significantly depends on factors other than your performance.
2 - Fixed pay is significantly below the market rate. That makes the variable pay look good in terms of percentage. 
3 - Work nature can get frustating, operational and less quant like. The role advertised would be state of the art R&D. The real work can be quite different from expectations.
4 - Management is sleeping and unaware of reality and without a care for the employees.
5- Work life balance is not great. The culture is to stay in office or WFH for long hours either working on projects or on management committees trying to make your name visible. The number of hours don't justify the compensation.
6 - No chance of relocation to business centers like London, NYC.
7 - Frequent cost cutting measures (cutting the office cabs, office overtime meals, etc. to save few tens of thousands rupees)
