headline: RUN FAR AWAY - TOXIC ENVIRONMENT
pros: There are none whatsoever. Toxic environment.
cons: People are mostly promoted by perverted old men, and if you're young, blond and beautiful, the sky is the limit. If you have years of experience, not 24 years old and blond, then prepare to be miserable, overworked, and underpaid. I had an emergency health situation and needed a life saving surgery, and my manager told me that this is a busy period and the surgery should be scheduled a year later. I explained that it's a life saving surgery, and i can't reschedule. He was furious, and prevented me from getting a bonus, or raise the following year (even though i was only out for a few weeks). Run far away and run fast. However, if you enjoy misery and a toxic environment, then please apply.

headline: Sales
pros: Great Company to work for just not this department. They have great pay and some of the best benefits I’ve seen. Vacation time is fantastic. The Firm has other great departments.
cons: Employment is not equal, Managers have their favorites, Males get the best pay, incentives and greater opportunities, job advancement opportunities travel opportunities. There’s no way to work towards equal pay or treatment. It’s based of kissing butt and who you know, bad leadership is my main concern. Minorities get the low end of the leads and they’re targeted when the department needs to cut down on staff. It’s all about preference, they pick and choose, keep your mouth shut and hope managers like you. I’ve seen talented people get bullied and forced to resign. They will find just about any reason to get rid of reps they don’t like, hostile environment. I would not recommend this place.

headline: Chase review

cons: Not willing to move up

headline: Good company to work for
pros: I would recommend applying for a job at J.P. Morgan, especially for young professionals. There is the platform and the room to progress, and all the tools available for career development if you are self-motivated. This is not the case in many (or most) companies. Also, you do not necessarily need a background in Finance to enter the company which is great if you are after a carreer change: you have your chances to get in and progress from there.
cons: the cons of working in a fast paced environment for a wide and international corporation...

headline: Good company, but the pay isn't the greatest...
pros:
- Good company to have on your resume, especially when it comes to brand and company recognition. 
- Like any company, it really depends on your location, your managers, and your colleagues. It's a roll of the dice. Some people have had a negative experience with their managers or the team that they're on. Personally, I like my team, the department I work in, and I enjoy my managers. 
- Flexible schedule. 5% 401K match. Good benefits. Good work life balance. Affordable insurance plans. Tuition reimbursement. Business casual dress code. Flexible with their tattoo policy.
- I feel like Chase has handled the COVID19 pandemic with ease, in my opinion. They've allowed us to work from home, kept us in the loop regarding any important updates, were understanding if we had computer issues, provided us with the necessary home equipment, provided us with extra sick time, and were overall really flexible.
cons:
- I started out as a phone agent in collections, and I was able to be promoted to a Real Time Analyst within a year. Perhaps I just got lucky. But over time, I've realized there is hardly any opportunity for promotions or career advancement. My suggestion would be to start out as a call center agent or any entry-level position, to at least get your foot in the door. Especially if you've just graduated high school or maybe need a decent recognizable brand on your resume. Since Chase is a large company, try and move up the corporate ladder if you're able to. 
- The biggest issue I have while working here, is the low pay. Despite having excellent annual reviews every year, management claims that I'm on the "high end" of the pay scale within my pay grade, and that I'm ineligible for a pay raise. But with Chase not offering any career advancement opportunities, I'm pigeonholed until I can find another job that pays more. So that's something to be mindful of.
- Like most call center environments, there can be gossip and drama. Try your best not to engage in any of that.

headline: Life at JPMC
pros: Stability of the firm in india
cons: Too small span of control

headline: great benefits but no work/life balance
pros: The health benefits, retirement, and time off are amazing.
cons: Constantly short staffed. Schedule changes weekly with very little consistency. no work/life balance. Customers are exceptionally grumpy because of long wait times to work with bankers in the branch. Bankers are coached to "change their mindset" when customers are yelling at them and to be sympathetic and understanding. Zero support is given by managers as they will not support staff when a customer is unhappy. Customer satisfaction surveys are given way too much importance.

headline: Great place to learn
pros: The job will help you work on a lot of core skills including, writing, critical thinking, public speaking, financial modelling and analysis, and relative valuation/idea generation. You also benefit from access to a broad array of resources working on the sell-side that may or may not be there on the buy-side. Overall, a great way to "cut your teeth" and learn many skills that you can take with you wherever you go.
cons: As a junior analyst you will most often need to look outwards (either for another role within J.P. Morgan or at a different company) for upward mobility given that the next rung on the "corporate ladder" in the group is to be senior analyst and those opportunities will depend on luck and timing (relocation can also be a way to make senior analyst. Not exactly a "con" but the other consideration you should think about is that you work in a small team so communication and developing rapport with the senior analyst you support is a MUST.

engineering excellency wont necessarily be rewarded as top priority for many managers is to keep a happy shop. 

not much technical growth but this might depend on teams.

project wise, little ownership for individuals. 2 reasons: 1. Singapore is not the dominant office . 2 bloated team structure.

headline: Cheap Fishbowl
pros: Salary paycheck and office is close to my residence now that we must return post pandemic.
cons:
Worse than the new typical collaborative “open office environment” concept seen in similar corporate facilities. The Plano campus consist of the new theme to squeeze as many people as possible into a fishbowl. This is even more pronounced in the IT Developer areas.

The company offers medical coverage but there is a tier system in place so the more successful you have been with your career expect to be penalized with higher cost of coverage (socialism mentality).

I joined as a software engineer and began during the pandemic time working remote. No laptop or any type of WFH stipend offered. Expected to use your home personal equipment to work via VPN. Return to office and must work from a shared computer where you log into a desktop with personal credentials to identify yourself as the user. This is so they can move you around at moment’s notice and save the fee on laptops. Kind of cheap for a billion-dollar company!

Company invested a lot of money into these new facilities pre-pandemic so now is forced to reject the work-from-home or even hybrid concept to justify real estate investment and receive local and state tax incentives. Nothing to do with collaboration. That is an excuse. Call it for what it is! 

If your political views don't lean to the far left this might not be the right fit from a culture perspective.

headline: Good Company, try to land in a good branch (if you're a banker)
pros: Overall, the company has all the tools to make your job easy and set you up for success. Your personal success as a banker depends on your location, your team, your manager and how willing you are to follow their guidance. Great PTO and benefits. Company-wide work culture is positive, open-minded, inclusive, and caring. There is definitely opportunity to grow if you put in the work and follow guidelines. There is a lot of structure and resources available to you, if you choose to utilize them.
cons: Your personal success as a banker depends on your location, your team, your manager, and how willing you are to follow their guidance. If you're in a good situation, you're in a great spot. If you're not in a good situation, it will be tough. Long-term growth is limited at the branch level/requires thinking outside your outlined job role growth to continue, but that does not necessarily mean you cannot make a good living, have a good life, or get where you want to be if you look for it. The Incentive plan for bankers changes every year, sometimes it gets drastically cut. Get used to making a lot of phone calls, as the company has geared towards this for the future.

headline: Chase Private Client Banker
pros:
-Great training platform.
- Awesome online resources and phone channel support.
- If you do your job you will make no less than $5,000 a month in PVC’s (commission)
- Storefront presence and your client know where to find you.
- Dress code was very flexible and they give you $125 spending allowance each year for Chase branded appeal.
cons:
-Most Chase locations are short staffed you will work 5-6 days a week after training is completed.
-Often it will be only 2 employees in the branch all day so taking lunch is very difficult. Might have to eat quickly in 10 minutes before the next client walks in. 
-VERY STRICT company, you have ZERO room for error and will get fired for a first mistake, no warnings given. You have to unlearn whatever you know from your previous banks.

headline: Great Place but Management Dependent
pros: Great salary, gain experience quickly and have the ability to change your job due to the size of the company (I have tried 3 different "jobs" in the last 3 years).
cons: Your experience working here is dependent on your direct manager (which is typical in most technology roles). If you are unlucky and get a manager that is like an overseer driving delivery like your team is a cog in a giant machine, you will be chewed up and spit out (burn out is real). If you get a REAL manager your experience will be amazing (speaking from experience).

headline: Good benefits, good incentives
pros:
- Substantial health insurance benefits as well as fringe benefits if you're located in a major city.
- Well-tailored incentive plan that generally aligns what is good for the customer with what's good for you
- Pays for licenses and has decent educational benefit if you plan on staying at least 3 years
cons:
- Large corporation, so not very responsive to employee feedback
- Sales job, so you're not getting a raise to base pay without an outside offer

headline: Wouldn't work here given other choices

headline: Good Experience Overall But Not the Workplace I Want
pros: It’s a comfortable job in the sense that there are codes of conduct, standards of behavior, and established roles. The pay is pretty good (at least in San Francisco) and the benefits are pretty good. Three weeks of paid vacation and annual onsite health screenings and flu vaccines are a couple of examples. The people are welcoming and warm initially and if you fit into the “finance culture,” you’ll do great here. You could even walk away with a few friends and mentors like I was able to.
cons: Lack of diversity is a huge issue in the industry and at JPM. The San Francisco office is supposed to be one of the most diverse and it still lacks greatly. Favoritism and popularity contests are rampant. Executive assistants are treated like waitstaff by many analysts and associates, even when the executives try to include them. The worst part is you can’t say anything about it because HR is useless. Turnover is high because people (not just executive assistants but at almost every level except top) are burnt-out and suppressing their true feeling in this environment. It’s exhausting to be in. It is a clique filled place to be. It’s also a huge company and assistants don’t bring in the money so you’re a number to them. Nothing more nothing less. Training is never really provided. You just get thrown in the deep end. hope your team is good to you.

headline: Go elsewhere
pros: Benefits are good. They do tend to keep people employed even when their lines of business are no longer needed. They will always try and keep the employee with Chase.
cons: If you work for Chase you will be using outdated systems , and when seeking new employment it makes you undesirable to hire. There are systems that are used so frequently in the industry and no other company wants to take the time to train you in them. Their work life balance is terrible. They pay significantly lower than other companies and you’re expected to do so much more than your average loan processor. I had to train myself to do my job basically. Training is poor and they tell you “you won’t need to know that” about so many aspects of your job. When in reality they are putting you at a disadvantage . Their training is very poor. Again, this makes you a very undesirable candidate for other companies even with years and years of experience !! I think it’s strategic. They just want to keep you there , underpay you and treat you like a number not a person. Their systems are from the 90s and they do not give their processors bonuses no matter how much you book for them.

headline: Deadbeat roles with low scope for growth or learning
pros:
1. Salary and benefits
2. Relaxed culture at times, if no pressure your team will take it real slow. The people in the company are also dull with no passion for programming.
3. No young crowd, poor place for fresher.
4. Good work-life balance
cons:
1. Don't be in the firing range when there are issues in production, that sucks you in and takes all your life for the next few days.
2. Poor salary growth within the firm
3. Ridiculous metrics for promotion. The only way to get promoted is to grow old in this company. Promotion is done on the basis of experience, or diversity.
4. Highly biased towards diversity candidates. I'm not saying it is wrong, we all require equal opportunity. But these people just go overboard and so you have a lot of incompetent women at high positions.

headline: The cons outweigh the pros
pros: Lots of ways to get involved, good benefits & # of PTO days, good amount of opportunity to learn
cons: Internal mobility is encouraged, but tons of bureaucracy during the actual job transfer. If you take a job that is posted as a salary grade above what you currently are, HR won't allow you to take the promotion or raise. It saves the company money because they could pay you less even though the skills and job requirements are worth more money (and they would have paid an external candidate more money).

headline: Just don't
pros:
Benefits are good, pay its ok.
Some of the coworkers are helpful
cons:
Management is not there to builds you up or support you or to lead you so you grow and become a better employee. They do everything to show you that you are incompetent, are rude, sometimes will scream at you, not helpful, if you are in doubt and need them they will ask you counter questions that will leave you even more confused. Will point out every single mistake and ask why? I get it but when you're working on hundreds of loans a month there will some mistakes. Even when you are in your learning stage. This is not coaching, this is standing behind you with a stick. Which makes Job extremely stressful and that leads to mistakes. And complaining to higher up Management doesn't do anything, even if you can prove unprofessional behavior. How big of a hypocrite you have to be to treat your employees poorly but with other people around be super nice...
They are news of return to office circling around, which is very unsafe. Why would you want to wear a mask and risk another sickness because of doing so if you can satisfactory perform your job from the comfort of your home office. 
I will tell you, its because management its supporting micromanagement and they don't trust anyone which is very sad in such reputable company as JPMorgan Wealth Management is, and wants to be.
You will think because Wealth Management is designated for high profile clients the operations will be treated good. But unfortunately that will be a lie.

headline: A good job that could have been GREAT.
pros:
-Base pay = $16.75/hr (much higher than most entry-level retail jobs)

-High-pressure, fast-pace, no slackers, lots of responsibility (this job is not for clowns)

-Full healthcare, dental, vision benefits for part-time employees (20-30 hrs/wk, great for HS grads just getting started)

-Moving up is easy or difficult depending on how bad you want it. You ultimately decide whether you move up with this company.
cons:
-Incompetent and lackluster managers, close-quarters workplace, corporate brown-nosing, volatile clients

-ANCIENT computer hardware and software, difficult to manage at times.

-They will laugh at you if you ask for more than 20 hrs/wk. Expect short and brutal shifts, random and revolving days off during the week, Saturdays are mandatory. All of this will somehow end up as 20 hrs/wk

headline: Great Teams - Challenging But Doable
pros: (NOTE: I last worked here in 2009, but I could not select that in the dropdown.) Since the company was large and well-resourced, we rarely had budgeting issues on projects. Although teamwork, collaboration, communication, negotiation and diplomacy is required to get the maximum from your cross-functional team, generally, we always had enough people on our project teams to do the work. Most everyone was reasonable and good to work with. You must be a great problem-solver, be able to hunt down solutions across multiple business areas and be able to deal with lots of personalities, but this is simply required of all project managers.
cons: There are often long hours and late or early morning hours due to international teams balancing time zone constraints. Balancing this job as well as young children would be challenging but doable if you are highly organized, prioritize well and commit to a fit and healthy lifestyle so that you can work as fast as you can in order to leave each day with enough time to handle your "second job" at home.

headline: Broad exposure to the firm

cons: The firm decision making can be quite political, meaning you miss big opportunities getting stuck in other people's agendas

headline: No work life balance for overworked employees
pros: Part time employees can get benefits. Corporate discounts on travel.
cons: I work full-time but I was contractually hired as a part time employee so I only qualify for part time benefits. We are always short staffed for being a busy branch. Tellers are gaining banker responsibilities with no pay increase or incentives. Personal banker positions are being removed, and they have only been given the two options of becoming tellers or Relationship Bankers which they need to get licensed to work. Relationship Bankers are overwhelmed and over booked with appointments. Internal promotion is almost impossible even when you meet most of the qualifications and have contacts in that current position vouching for you to work there, something about "HR Politics". JPMC had their highest earnings in the first quarter of this year and their employees got a congratulatory E-mail for all our hard work.

pros: They used to hire smart people and there is still a lot of them aground. Pay is reasonable, but not linked to performance.

headline: Return to Work
pros: Co-workers, paid time off, and attempts to support career growth
cons: Getting hired is based on who you know not what you know. Lack of respect and consideration of employees wants and needs. After working from home for 15 months, senior leadership arbitrarily decided we should return to work in the office. There was no consultation with people doing the job, complete disrespect for us. It’s clear they intend to return to pre-pandemic, little wfh flexibility options other than a day here or there. Obviously the decision was made with the mindset of a long gone business model. Good people will leave because remote work is the wave of now. They are making efforts to diversify leadership but many feel it’s just for show. Same for career advancement and growth opportunities ,

headline: JPMorgan Chase Mostly Cons and a few Pros
pros: JPMorgan Chase offers great benefits. The health insurance and life insurance benefits are very good and the out of pocket expenses are very reasonable compared to other companies. They have a legal benefit that is very inexpensive and well worth it. It's nice to be able to have free checking and savings accounts for the whole family. I like the fact that the company is very ethnically diverse. The company always makes it a point to make sure that it's on the forefront of all the latest technology only for customer facing applications and systems.
cons:
*The company has grown too large and is out of control with too much red tape and bureaucracy. 
--It takes too long to get anything approved and there are too many manager approval levels involved. 
*Senior managers are involved with approving menial expenses instead of spending time on more important issues and concerns. 
*The company is top heavy with far too many directors, managing directors and executives, and there are far too few employees to actually take care of business and do real work. 
*JPMC does at least 3 rounds of layoffs each year, and each time they layoff more mid level and entry level employees that do the work.
--Consequently, those employees that are left to do the work end up doing the job of 3 - 4 people. 
*Also, it's very important to note, that when they do the 3 rounds of layoffs each year, they target workers that are 55 years and older. 
--So while JPMC is constantly bragging to the media and to their employees that they champion diversity and inclusion and that they don't practice discrimination of any kind, they are clearly and openly discriminating against workers that are 55 years or older. 
*Global Technology Infrastructure is the worst line of business to work for because the company treats GTI as an expense. 
--If you're going to work for JPMC, it's best to work for one of the other lines of business such as Chase Investment Bank, Asset Wealth Management, Commercial Bank or Mortgage Banking. 
*JPMC makes internal applications and systems for employees their lowest priority, and it makes it very difficult to get work done. 
--In addition, JPMC has gotten rid of most of the help desks where employees could talk to someone to get help.
--Unfortunately, if you are having issues with an application or tool that you need to get your work done, you will be relegated to opening a ticket through a clumsy automated system and it could be several days before anyone addresses your issue.

headline: Pros and Cons to everything

I started my career at JPMorgan out of college so they're great for that.
You make a lot of connections and friends as well.
With a big company such as JPMC, you'll find it difficult to not find a role you'd probably enjoy.
cons:
You can get pigeon-holed into doing stuff that nobody wants.
There's a lot of people who get promoted just out of circumstance and really shouldn't be in a managerial position.
The salary is very low in comparison to other companies.

headline: Lowest base salary in the field
pros: Great benefits, it used to have a decent incentive plan.
cons: Too many changes. They expect private client bankers to pick up the slack when they layoff other positions. They are so demanding with productivity and calls. Expect you to do your job and cover for other roles and manager when they’re not there. They also made most bankers managers on duty to cover when manager is absent. Without any pay or bonus for the much added responsibility which will distract you from doing your actual job that makes you money to compensate for the embarrassing low base, even when you make good commission you are heavily taxed on it which at the end of the day you are better off have a high guaranteed salary. Because they change the incentive plan on you with just 1 week notice. Also no flexibility to work from home or have access to at least an email. Chase have changes a lot it’s all about the big bosses pockets and not their employees that are the ones that doing all the hard core job and hustling to bring new clients and new money.

headline: Great place to grow
pros:
-Outstanding Career Progression
I started as a fraud specialist, moved to auto financial service advisor, then recruitment sr. specialist until finally I became a Reference Data Analyst which is really a Project Management Role. This all happened in a span of 5 years. If you're interested of growing your career and really moving up the corporate ladder, this is really a great company for that.
-Teaches you the importance of finances
Before this company, I hated credit cards, loans, and vehicles in general. They gave me the financial knowledge to understand how to manage this privileges to bring me to the next level. At the age of 29, I already have a condo, a wife, and a car without the help of relatives or parents. I'm not even earning that much!
cons:
-Old culture
There will be a road block someday as people tend to see years of experience is better than a yuppy who has a heart. You just have to really prove them wrong.
-No nonsense work environment. I actualy like this but I'm certain some others won't.
-Love of frugality
Love it or hate it. This is the reason why the company is striving against the others. Upper management does get mores bonuses than the little one and hey I'm getting some of the benefits since I'm in the middle. I do see how sad it is at the bottom.

headline: Your happiness can vary depending on location
pros: Benefits, career growth and opportunities, decent bonus opportunity, great place to network as well.
cons: As a banker it can be very difficult to get time needed (not wanted) time off. Some locations require you to work weekends and depending on location they may only approved one person to be off on any given day (so good luck if you are competing with senior bankers for a day off in December.) Your overall happiness depends on management and it's difficult to know their management style until you've already been placed at a branch. Transfers can be a little tricky to achieve at times as well.

headline: Easy money, if you're mentally well.
pros:
-Pay is okay, I started at 16/hr and went up to 17.22/hr in a year. 
-Just sit and take calls all day. 
-Assisting customers is fairly easy most of the time.
cons:
-People scream at you for things you can't control and you're expected to just take it, even when customers are down right rotten. 
-Health insurance is crap. 
-Reaching out to team leaders is difficult as they're always in meetings. 
-Just sitting all days. 
-Sometimes the calls are back to back to back. 
-If you're a minute late, it counts against you. A minute early? Counts against you. Can't work home? Too bad.

headline: Terrible Culture
pros:
-good opportunities to learn (global morning meeting call)
-a few decent people that will support you during your time there and beyond
-salary
cons:
I have PTSD from working here especially as 1) a woman 2) a person of color. Forget it. Save yourself. It’s an awful culture. They act like this is IB when it’s not. Not everything has to be so urgent. They will talk down on you if you’re a woman and again especially if you’re POC. It’s a white male dominated industry. That will never change. Wake up! It’s 2021. The women who work here are intense because they have to be and in turn I never felt supported by them. They felt like they worked hard to get to where they were and that’s that. 

There is so much bureaucracy.

I was also client facing but the client service associates who do all the back end work deserve to be paid more. That will reduce turnover and make them a bit happier.

So many politics. I hate office politics more than anything and this is one place people will backstab you. Be prepared.

They also hate when you want a higher education. Beware. I’m going for my MBA now and they laugh at that.

I would have stayed for the actual work but the culture is just so, so awful.

headline: Not a company for tech employees
pros:
Free on-site medical clinic is nice
Columbus McCoy center is awesome with plenty of food options.
cons:
Job grades need modernized; there are 2 levels of associate and then you become a VP. Trying to get promoted to VP is nearly impossible because it’s not about merit but how many executive directors you know. If you come from tech with levels like engineer 1-5 and principal engineer and the ability to easily get promoted then steer clear. 
Bonuses are under par from most other tech companies, my other employers had targets like 10-15% but at Chase they give you no idea; my bonuses were 7% and 9%. They only care about making bankers and brokers happy not the people keeping the systems working. 
Raises are very poor after 1 year I was not given a raise and told my 7% bonus was high which is why I started looking for new jobs, the next year I only got 2%.
401k matching is horrible, they do not match every pay check and will deposit the funds January the following year if you are still employed. 

No one takes responsibility for their products, if you have an issue with a system good luck trying to get support and it fixed. I had open tickets for bugs for 8 months that were never resolved. Most documentation is nonexistent or outdated.
I understand having to deal with risks and audits but the people managing risk are incompetent. They will say you need to fix this but tell you no information on how to or where to find resources. The whole SDLC risk team have the worst archaic system for getting an application from dev to prod, you have to paste screenshots in excel documents and post it to sharepoint. Every tollgate basically asks the same questions and you just end up copying and pasting from one worksheet to another.
I was told our team would hire new employees to help alleviate the team workload and over a year later they finally opened a couple contractor roles not even FTE as promised. By that time I was burnt out and already planning on leaving. 

Health benefits were great before changing MRA requirements, before you did some activities every quarter to get funds but last year they switched to making you wear a step counter and walk 7,500 steps 20 days a month. I don’t like wearing watches or things so I just decided to forfeit about $500.

cons: Extremely long hours, siloed roles. Despite 6 straight record breaking quarters of revenue in the billions, raises are stalled at 1-2% and bonuses are flat. (Also around 1-2%). This has been true since 2018 and has not changed. If they are not paying them now they’re certainly not going to bring them back in the future. Be warned. headline: Solid corporate job
pros: Stable company, moving towards newer technologies will allow to learn new tools as Chase implements them in the company. Heavily works with AWS (Chase specific) and kubernetes. Moving internally is easy and if you don't like your team, Chase has one to fit your skillset or what you want to do. Chase also has a great entry level (college graduate) software engineering program (SEP), which will place you on a team that best fits your interests and skillset.
cons: Almost everything is "Chase specific", nearly 35-40% of what I learned while at this company cannot be carried over outside of Chase. Cyber regulations don't stop for applications that are external facing and even for internal facing applications it can be difficult and time consuming to comply with the restrictions.

headline: JPMorgan Asset Management is basically a back office!
pros: Relaxed jobs, fixed hours, work of home is now very prevalent owing to covid.
cons: It's just a back office in India, JPMorgan Asset Management does not have a front end presence in India. So naturally, it is a cost center for them - not as lucrative as JP Morgan IB which is their front end business in India. But obviously, the talent there is also top tier. The senior management sitting here are just earning like anything without doing any work, so they don't want to move anywhere - hence, no scope for juniors. Repetitive work, you won't be challenged - the kind of work which can be done by a 12th pass. Basically a lot of support activities are being run from here - the kind of work folks in other global offices don't want to do. Very slow career progression - seen analysts with more than 10-11 years of experience.

headline: Micro Management In Action
pros: The salary is quite high for the UK.
cons:
My base is in Europe but management in the US took full control (remotely) of our local office and tried to impose the same style of working as our colleagues have to endure in India, i.e. endless out of hours work, don't talk back and don't share your views or experience.

All levels of management above me are Indian, both locally and remotely. Presumably because they are used to this type of work culture.

More senior staff are being let go, and the junior staff retained, as they can be re-trained to be unthinking robots.

Customers are quite rude at times but we must always have "customer obsession". This was the first time I don't want to wake up to work, your quality life is gone. headline: State of the art, but boring in the long run
author_position: Cyber Security Incident Response and Attack Analyst
pros:
good salary
great benefits (27 days vacation, amazing pension plan)
most people around are great.
You will get your hand dirty with an unbelievable amount of tools. Think about a technology, it is there in use.
When you are done for the day you are really done.
cons:
US centric company, meaning cool projects are done mainly in the US and other regions gets the boring leftovers. 
Internal reorg wanted people to focus on some areas, which means it gets more repetitive.
Not tiered monitoring model, which means even after years you will be due to work "shift weeks" which are very stressful and repetitive, especially during hiring freezes where workload is essentially double.
Requires to answer the phone (call center like) from internal employees that want to report security issues.
It is going to take long time to progress internally. 
I would personally recommend this role to someone not very senior to get more experience, or if you get the Senior role which does not require the monthly shift work.
Management does not say anything about people working more hours than they should, and this is actually appreciated rather than discouraged.

headline: The job can be soul crushing, but the pay and benefits are nice
pros:
They have other benefits, but I only cared about these:
Health insurance benefits
401K contributions
Cheap Gym Membership
Good Pay for no college degree necessary
2019 they gave every employee a free turkey (Supposed to be yearly, but 2020 we all worked from home)
Fairly generous time off allowances (You can take Leave of Absences for Maternity, Bereavement, etc.)
They say that they drug test, but its randomly selected so you have a decently high chance of not being chosen
cons:
You're a debt collector; A lot of the calls will be pretty repetitive as you're just catching people up on their bills, but every once in a while, you'll get a really depressing call where they tell you their entire life story and they cry and stuff. You aren't really here to help them. You're supposed to negotiate and compromise with the company's interest at heart which made me feel a little dirty and heartless at times. You're basically a salesperson trying to sell "no debt" to a captive audience. On top of that, they try to create a positive, lighthearted environment which clashes really hard with the nature of the work at times, and it feels super cringe. Imagine listening to someone explain that they've been laid off and are having money issues while someone is blasting pop music and handing you candy. That literally happened to me once. I only really stayed as long as I have because of the pay and benefits

Standards can be a little hard to hit consistently. It feels like the luck of the draw. Your ability to sell to people without money will make or break you.

Typical customer service issues: demanding and entitled customers, idiots, high call volume at times, strict scheduling, team leaders can be unavailable, lazy, out of touch etc.

headline: Go Anywhere else but here!!!
pros: Only good thing is the annual CEO bonus of $750. Everything else is unpredictable & definitely not worth the risks, so stay where you are, don't join JP Morgan!
cons:
Truly an American firm - suck the life out of employees to keep the shareholders happy.
Horrible Work-Life Balance (expect 12-14 hour workday)
Petty politics at mid-higher level
Managers treat people as machines who need to work continuously.
They push people to automate tasks and then shove more work their way regardless of their interests
Manager is very powerful, no 360 degree feedback appreciated by them. If you don't conform to what they ask you to do, you are screwed badly.
Worst part is HR is used as henchmen to shove more work your way and they always side with the managers.

headline: Working for little to no incentives or recognition
pros: None really, but could be completely dependent on my market. Wait, I did have fun at some events I went to and the places I got to volunteer with. I had some amazing clients who I will miss so so much.
cons:
Don’t expect to get credit and move up for bringing in any money if your manager doesn’t have that type of supportive vibe up front. I’ve never been more used. No scorecards; PB role is now gone; and RBs & PCBs no longer credit you for your referrals. When I first started I could atleast get paid for getting people to open accounts and credit cards, and referring them to our HLA & PCB and other associates. But now I get nothing and absolutely no recognition while fattening up others jackets, with numbers that wouldn’t exist if I didn’t personally take the time to find them our individual customers, face to face. I thought if I worked harder I’d actually move. Found leads bigger than some of our RBs and got customers to bring in serious $$$$ after introducing them to our associates and PCBs and my BM & PCB got a bonus; They got recognized. What did I get? Not a promotion. But I was saddled with the responsibility of two roles w bs pay, no incentives, no scorecards and wasted time. A product of bad management. “Diversity & inclusion” a lie
The only reason I stayed so long is because I had a handful of amazing women as me who’ve since moved on.

headline: Brilliant Organization.
pros:
Certainly one of the best place to work. 

1. Technology centric. Latest technology stack is followed and upgraded with time. 
2. Compensation. Salary is never a problem. Year on year growth is good. They also give a very high IC. 
3. Opportunity. If you want to work on something. Just say it. Management will try their best to give you the same. 
4. Benefits. All standard benefits like Good number of leaves. Good insurance cover etc. They also provide free transportation. 
5. Good work-life balance. 
6. Learning and Development. They give free pluralsight access, O'Reilly subscription and many more. Learning is encouraged here.
cons:
1. Promotion process is a bit tough. You need to deliver consistently for 2-3 years and be a fast mover. 
2. Getting a leadership role is difficult as there are many people in the queue. You need to be the best in the race. 
3. Large applications to work on hence it can be sometimes complex to deliver. 
4. Visibility of HR to general employees is very limited. They just have one platform to ask everything.

headline: Depends on Market - Chase Consumer Banking
pros: I worked in two vastly different markets starting with a major metropolitan city and then moving to a small, remote market in Texas and the difference in professionalism was shocking. Everything from the technology, practices, and management were all very disappointing. I could have received a major promotion from my role had it not been for the mismanagement and restrictive policies in this market. Overall, I have seen others get lucky moving up, and others never get lucky, waiting forever for that promotion that never comes. I believe all of them to be equally capable. Thus, it comes down to your management and if they care or not. I happen to be in a market with poor management. Unfortunately, after all the time invested in this company, I will have to move on to something else in order to achieve any reasonable career objectives.
cons: To be honest, there is a lot of publicity about diversity and inclusion but again, this depends on your market, and your manager at the ground level. Some markets have more visibility and therefore it's easier to get noticed whereas others are sort of lost in the shuffle.

headline: It all depends on your branch and team
pros: If you get a good branch this can be a very lucrative job, with six figure earning potential. There are a lot of great advisors and bankers in this organization to learn from. Chase has great benefits, and you start off with a decent amount of vacation.
cons: Coworkers and other branches can be pretty cutthroat and will steal leads that you are already working with. A lot of the top performers are "gifted" their leads from the advisors, and get credit for closing a lot of business when they don't actually do much work. While management frowns on gifting it's actually pretty rampant. Also, way to much emphasis is put on Salesforce metrics...

headline: Diversity, Respect, and Overall Great Company Values
pros:
Diversity, Respect, and Overall Great Company Values
Compensation
Dependents for HMO
If you feel like you are or anyone is not being treated well as per company values, you can report anonymously and HR and Security will support and help you. They have a NO Retaliation Policy. You dont have to be afraid to speak up. I have full confidence that JPMC has my back always for things like this.
cons: Call Volume is really High on peak season that extends for months on end. BUT it is a small price to pay for the good stuff you get like pay, well matured and professional culture of the company

headline: Work 18 hours a day and belittle your co-workers
pros: If you enjoy working all hours of the day/night and having your boss checking on you constantly to be sure you are logged in and available, this is the company for you! If you enjoy hearing a department "leader" (Managing Director) tell your India counterparts that their English is bad, this is the place for you! If you want to hear from your immediate boss that she inherited you in a role that is not her specialty (and she is not happy about it), this is the place for you! If you want to work for a company where you feel unwelcome, this is the place for you!
cons: My experience was so bad, I refinanced my home so my mortgage is with another lender. I would not give JPMC another dime of my money. I will never bank with them. Very unorganized company. Internal technology needs to catch up to the times. People work non-stop because processes are so manual. The long-tenured associates like to do things "the way they've always done them" even if it means it's more time-consuming and they dedicate all their time to this institution. If you work here, you will not have a life outside work. They also like you to log your whereabouts when you are on vacation. It's an invasion of privacy.

headline: Great work/life balance
pros: JPMorgan has been consistently wonderful in providing a great work/life balance, allowing time off on short notice, understanding of family situations, and allowing work to be completed on a schedule that is best for me. JPM is also the most diverse workplace I've experienced.
cons: Compensation is considerably lower than other banks; raises can be small or nonexistent, and bonuses are discretionary. If you are hired at a lower salary it is very difficult to achieve higher salary levels in your role's compensation band. Additionally, health insurance offers a decent range of doctors but deductibles are high and non-deductible, non-covered out of pocket expenses can be significant.

headline: Two swimming lanes
pros: JP Morgan is a machine, it has a lot of money to throw at its biggest problems and will not hesitate to hire the best people to do the job it needs.
cons: For management, it’s a revolving door. New hires are given the hardest jobs, expected to fail after a period and discarded as and when it happens. Often senior people brought into roles that 3-4 people are already responsible for in other areas in the firm. Be sure to enter at a high comp level, it often stagnates once your through the door and comp is targeted at the junior levels.

headline: Great to get your foot in the door, no future in this department however
pros: Very visible role, exposure to lots of senior executives and high-profile clients. If you can do a good job and get the ear of the right people, you can go far.
cons: No upward mobility, management is a sham - they only promote “friends” and seems to have no basis on actual performance. In fact, performance metrics (when brought up in meetings) are never considered and so lots of people just don’t do their job and in order to keep clients happy you have to do it or your team suffers. Lots of attrition because of this.

headline: Overview
pros:
- financial stability and security , total comp benefits such as healthcare, dental care etc. 
Career development - pretty much straight trajectory from grad scheme to associate and from them onwards it’s about you and how to market yourself. 

Large company so good opportunity for exposure and networking.

Large employee base with various business resource groups that foster a diverse and inclusive culture. 

Big push from CEO and senior management on diversity and inclusion
cons:
- Long hours, poor work life balance 
- Large company
- Lots of mundane, repetitive boring tasks with 0 value that needs to be performed.
- Heavily regulated industry with lots of bureaucracy and meaningless processes all in the name of compliance
- Finance can really stifle curiosity and passion for learning new concepts
- unless you’re in a revenue generating function, quiet hard to be motivated or feel the value add of what you do. We all know what we do is important to someone but that’s about it

headline: Slow moving giant, though good place to work
pros:
I worked here as a full time software developer for almost 5 years. It was good experience, following are the pros:
--1) Company provides good benefits like daily food allowance, free transport, health insurance etc.
--2) WFH was not allowed in general (as per office policy), but there were lenient teams which allowed the team-members to do WFH.
--3) As a software developer I enjoyed flexible working hours, no micro-management.
--4) There was not much of learning in the first half of my stint in the company, but in the second half learned a lot of new technologies.
--5) Was hired with a handsome pay package.
--6) Good place to learn about investment domain. That will help you if you want to grow in BFSI companies.
cons:
--1) It is a gigantic and slow moving company. They don't adapt cutting edge technologies rapidly. Hence, there was not much of learning in the first half of my stint in the company.
--2) They will pay you very good package while hiring you, but after that yearly increment and promotion policies are not that attractive.
--3) Moving to new project is not easy.
--4) Not much of traveling opportunity.
--5) Year-end bonus is much less than its competitors.

headline: Good luck breaking through glass ceilings here
pros: You will get paid on time
cons: Chase has a way of piling excess work and management responsibilities on people who are not in management. They keep a skeleton crew, and set people up to fail with too many impossible expectations and not enough staff or support. I was physically menaced by another employee, and received criticism for reporting it to HR. The other employee received no consequence. Know for a fact that you are only a number to this company: they will pay you as little as they can get away with, squeeze everything they can out of you, and leave you feeling too exhausted to do anything else. Don't work here if you can help it.
